member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.RegisterCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PointShape,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PointShape,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit)
member.summary: This method returns a BaseShape which has been registered from its original coordinate system to another based on two anchor PointShapes.

returns.para: This method returns a BaseShape which has been registered from its original coordinate system to another based on two anchor PointShapes.

remarks.para: Registering allows you to take a geometric shape generated in a planar system and attach it to the ground in a Geographic Unit.

A common scenario is integrating geometric shapes from external programs (such as CAD software or a modeling system) and placing them onto a map. You may have the schematics of a building in a CAD system and the relationship between all the points of the building are in feet. You want to then take the CAD image and attach it to where it really exists on a map. You would use the register method to do this.

Registering is also useful for scientific modeling, where software models things such as a plume of hazardous materials or the fallout from a volcano. The modeling software typically generates these models in a fictitious planar system. You would then use the register to take the abstract model and attach it to a map with real coordinates.

member.exception: If you pass in a fromUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a toUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
Passing a null as the fromPoint parameter will throw an ArgumentNullException.
Passing a null as the toPoint parameter will throw an ArgumentNullException.
member.param: This parameter is the anchor PointShape in the coordinate of origin.
This parameter is the anchor PointShape in the coordinate of destination.
This parameter is the DistanceUnit of the coordinate of origin.
This parameter is the GeographyUnit of the coordinate of destination.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.TranslateByOffsetCore(System.Double,System.Double,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit)
member.summary: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an X and Y offset distance.
member.overloads: In this overload, the X and Y offset are based on a DistanceUnit you specify, regardless of the shape's GeographicUnit.

remarks.para: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an X and Y offset distance. With this overload, it is important to note that the X and Y offset units are based on the distanceUnit parameter. For example, if your shape is in decimal degrees and you call this method with an X offset of 1 and a Y offset of 1, you're going to move this shape 1 unit of the distanceUnit in the horizontal direction and one unit of the distanceUnit in the vertical direction. In this way, you can easily move a shape in decimal degrees five miles to on the X axis and 3 miles on the Y axis.

member.exception: If you pass in a distanceUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a shapeUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method from a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This is the number of horizontal units of movement in the DistanceUnit specified as the distanceUnit.
This is the number of horizontal units of movement in the DistanceUnit specified as the distanceUnit.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

param.name: distanceUnit
param.para: This is the DistanceUnit you would like to use as the measure for the move. For example, if you select miles as your distanceUnit, then the xOffsetDistance and yOffsetDistance will be calculated in miles.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.TranslateByDegreeCore(System.Double,System.Double,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit)
member.summary: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on a distance and a direction in degrees.
member.overloads: In this overload, the distance is in the same GeographicUnit as the shape.

remarks.para: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an angleInDegrees and distance parameter. With this overload, it is important to note that the distance units are the same GeographicUnit as the shape. For example, if your shape is in decimal degrees and you call this method with a distance of 1, you're going to move this shape 1 decimal degree in direction of the angleInDegrees. In many cases it is more useful to specify the DistanceUnit of movement, such as in miles or yards, so for these scenarios there is another overload you may want to use instead.
If you pass a distance of 0, then the operation is ignored.

member.exception: Passing an invalid angleInDegrees which is not between 0 and 360 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method from a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
Passing an invalid distance which is not greater than or equal to 0 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.param: The distance is the number of units to move the shape in the angle specified. The distance unit will be the same as the GeographyUnit for the shape. The distance must be greater than or equal to 0.

param.name: angleInDegrees
param.para: A number between 0 and 360 degrees that represents the direction you wish to move the shape, with 0 being up.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

param.name: distanceUnit
param.para: This is the DistanceUnit you would like to use as the measure for the move. For example, if you select miles as your distanceUnit, then the xOffsetDistance and yOffsetDistance will be calculated in miles.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.RotateCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PointShape,System.Single)
member.summary: This method rotates the shape a number of degrees based on a pivot point.

remarks.para: This method rotates the shape a number of degrees based on a pivot point. By placing the pivot point in the center of the shape, you can achieve in-place rotation. By moving the pivot point outside of the center of the shape, you can translate the shape in a circular motion. Moving the pivot point further outside of the center will make the circular area larger.

member.exception: If you pass a null as the pivotPoint, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
Passing an invalid degreeAngle which is not between 0 and 360 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which is not valid, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.

param.name: pivotPoint
param.para: The pivotPoint represents the center of rotation.

param.name: degreeAngle
param.para: The number of degrees of rotation required from 0 to 360.

member.returns: A PointShape representing the closest point of the current shape to the targetShape.
member.exception: If you pass in a targetShape which does not have any points, we will throw an ArgumentException.

member.remarks: This method returns the point of the current shape that is closest to the target shape. It is often the case that the point returned is not a point of the object itself. An example would be a line with two points that are far apart from each other. If you set the targetShape to be a point midway between the points but a short distance away from the line, the method would return a point that is on the line but not either of the two points that make up the line.

param.name: targetShape
param.para: The shape you are trying to find the closest point to.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.GetWellKnownTextCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingOrder)
member.summary: This method returns the well-known text representation of this shape.
member.returns: This method returns a string that represents the shape in well-known text.

remarks.para: This method returns a string that represents the shape in well-known text. Well-known text allows you to describe a geometry as a string of text. Well-known text is useful when you want to save a geometry in a format such as a text file, or when you simply want to cut and paste the text between other applications. An alternative to well-known text is well-known binary, which is a binary representation of a geometry object. We have methods that work with well-known binary as well. Below are some samples of what well-known text might look like for various kinds of geometric shapes.
POINT(5 17)
LINESTRING(4 5,10 50,25 80)

member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.GetWellKnownBinaryCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingOrder,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WkbByteOrder)
member.summary: This method returns a byte array that represents the shape in well-known binary.
member.returns: This method returns a byte array that represents the shape in well-known binary.
member.remarks: This method returns a byte array that represents the shape in well-known binary. Well-known binary allows you to describe a geometry as a binary array. Well-known binary is useful when you want to save a geometry in an efficient format using as little space as possible. An alternative to well-known binary is well-known text, which is a textual representation of a geometry object. We have methods that work with well-known text as well.
member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
If you pass in a ByteOrder that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.param: This parameter specifies whether the byte order is big- or little-endian.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.LoadFromWellKnownDataCore(System.String)
member.summary: This method returns the center point of the current shape's bounding box.
member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.returns: A PointShape representing the center point of the current shape's bounding box.
member.remarks:
This method returns the center point of the current shape's bounding box. It is important to note that this is the center point of the bounding box. There are numerous ways to calculate the "center" of a geometry, such as its weighted center, etc. You can find other centers by examining the various methods of the shape itself.
Overriding:
Please ensure that you validate the parameters being passed in and raise the exceptions defined above.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PolygonShape.ValidateCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationMode)
member.summary: This method returns a ShapeValidationResult based on a series of tests.
member.returns: This method returns a ShapeValidationResult based on a series of tests.
member.remarks: We use this method, with the simple enumeration, internally before doing any kind of other methods on the shape. In this way, we are able to verify the integrity of the shape itself. If you wish to test things such as whether a polygon self-intersects, we invite you to call this method with the advanced ShapeValidationMode. One thing to consider is that for complex polygon shapes this operation could take some time, which is why we only run the basic, faster test. If you are dealing with polygon shapes that are suspect, we suggest you run the advanced test.
member.exception: If you pass in a validationMode that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.param: This parameter determines whether the test is simple or advanced. In some cases, the advanced tests can take some time. The simple test is designed to always be fast.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Proj4Projection
member.summary: This projection class uses the Proj4 engine to project data from one Srid to another.
member.remarks:
This projection class uses the Proj4 engine to project data from one Srid to another. Proj4 is a very popular projection library the support thousands for projections. It uses a special text format to feed in parameters about the to and from projection. Though it uses its own format many organizations have recognized it and provide their projection definition in this format. Within this class we support the latest EPSG (European Petroleum Survey Group) SRID (Spatial Reference System Identifiers) list. You can find more information about these on the web. The SRID list is very popular and we include a text version with in our install.
Note that one thing that confuses people is that when they go to or from latitude and longitude they do not know what SRID to use. The proper SRID is 4326 for WGS84 pair coordinates in degrees with Greenwich as the central meridian.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Proj4Projection.#ctor
member.summary: This is the default constructor for this class.
member.remarks: This conctructor pass nothing. After this cconstructor , you should set the InternalProjectionParametersString property and ExternalProjectionParametersString property before open to use.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Proj4Projection.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: This is a constructor for the class.
member.overloads: This constructor allows you to pass in Proj4 text parameters for the to and from projection. The parameters typically look like "+proj=longlat +ellps=WGS84 +datum=WGS84 +no_defs"
member.returns: None
member.remarks: This constructor allows you to pass in Proj4 text parameters for the to and from projection. The parameters typically look like "+proj=longlat +ellps=WGS84 +datum=WGS84 +no_defs" You should use this constructor when you know the parameters. If you know the SRID directly you can use the other constructor that takes the SRID.
member.param: This parameter is the projection parameters describing the data.
This parameter is the projection parameters describing the projection you want to go to.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Proj4Projection.InternalProjectionParametersString
member.summary: Gets or sets the Proj4 text parameter for the from projection. This parameter typically look like "+Proj=longlat +ellps=WGS84 +datum=WGS84 +no_defs".

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Proj4Projection.ExternalProjectionParametersString
member.summary: Gets or sets the Proj4 text parameter for the to projection. This parameter typically look like "+proj=utm +zone=33 +ellps=WGS84 +towgs84=0,0,0,0,0,0,0 +units=m +no_defs".

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Proj4Projection.OpenCore
member.returns: None
member.remarks:
As this is the core version of the Open method it is intended to be overridden in inherited version of the class. When overriding you will be responsible for getting the projection classes state ready for doing projections.
In this override we call the Proj4 methods get it ready for projection.
member.summary: This method open the projection and gets it ready to use.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Proj4Projection.CloseCore
member.summary: This method closes the projection and gets it ready to serialization if necessary.
member.returns: None
member.remarks:
As this is the core version of the Close method it is intended to be overridden in inherited version of the class. When overriding you will be responsible freeing any state you have maintained and getting the class ready to serialization if necessary. Note that the object may be opened again so you want to make sure you can open and close the object multiple tiles without any ill effects.
In this override we call the Proj4 methods get release the handles and memory.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Projection
member.summary: This class represents a projection that you wish to apply to a FeatureSource.
member.remarks: This class is abstract and designed to be inherited to create your own projection. The derived projection classes are typically used on a FeatureSource or Layer. It is used to project coordinates from one projection to another and back again. It is important to note that you need to implement the projection both ways.

member.remarks: None

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Projection.IsOpen
member.summary: This property gets the state of the projection (whether it is opened or closed).
member.decimalDegreesValue: This property gets the state of the projection (whether it is opened or closed).
member.remarks: This method will reflect whether the projection is opened or closed. It is set in the concrete methods Open and Close, so if you inherit from this class and override OpenCore or CloseCore, you will not need to be concerned with setting this property.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Projection.CloneDeep
member.summary: Create a copy of Projection using the deep clone process.
member.returns: A cloned Projection.
member.remarks: The difference between deep clone and shallow clone is as follows: In shallow cloning, only the object is copied; the objects within it are not. By contrast, deep cloning copies the cloned object as well as all the objects within.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.Projection.Open
member.remarks:
This method opens the projection and gets it ready to use.
As this is a concrete public method that wraps a Core method, we reserve the right to add events and other logic to pre- or post-process data returned by the Core version of the method. In this way, we leave our framework open on our end, but also allow you the developer to extend our logic to suit your needs. If you have questions about this, please contact our support team as we would be happy to work with you on extending our framework.

member.summary: This method increases the size of the area shape by the percentage given in the percentage parameter.

member.param: This is the percentage by which to increase the shape's size.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape.GetBoundingBoxCore
member.summary: This method calculates the smallest RectangleShape that encompasses the entire geometry.
member.returns: The RectangleShape returned is the smallest RectangleShape that can encompass the entire geometry.

remarks.para: The GetBoundingBox method calculates the smallest RectangleShape that can encompass the entire geometry by examining each point in the geometry.
Depending on the number of PointShapes and complexity of the geometry, this operation can take longer for larger objects.
If the shape is a PointShape, then the bounding box's upper left and lower right points will be equal. This will create a RectangleShape with no area.

member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method on this shape which has invalid upper left and lower right points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.

member.summary: This method returns a MultipointShape which has been registered from its original coordinate system to another based on two anchor PointShapes.
member.returns: This method returns a MultipointShape which has been registered from its original coordinate system to another based on two anchor PointShapes.
member.remarks: The register method is useful, for example, when a group of points represented by a MultipointShape has been generated in a non-geographic coordinate in meters, and you want to plot the points on a map that is in decimal degrees.
member.exception: If you pass in a fromUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a toUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on this shape which has invalid upper left and lower right points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This parameter is the anchor PointShape in the coordinate of origin.
This parameter is the anchor PointShape in the coordinate of destination.
This parameter is the GeographyUnit of the coordinate of origin.
This parameter is the GeographyUnit of the coordinate of destination.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape.TranslateByOffsetCore(System.Double,System.Double,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit)
member.summary: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an X and Y offset distance.
member.overloads: In this overload the X and Y offset are based on a DistanceUnit you specify regardless of the shape's GeographicUnit.

remarks.para: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an X and Y offset distance. With this overload, it is important to note that the X and Y offset units are based on the distanceUnit parameter. For example, if your shape is in decimal degrees and you call this method with an X offset of 1 and a Y offset of 1, you're going to move this shape 1 unit of the distanceUnit in the horizontal direction and one unit of the distanceUnit in the vertical direction. In this way, you can easily move a shape in decimal degrees five miles to on the X axis and 3 miles on the Y axis.

member.exception: If you pass in a distanceUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a shapeUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method from a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This is the number of horizontal units of movement in the DistanceUnit specified as the distanceUnit.
This is the number of horizontal units of movement in the DistanceUnit specified as the distanceUnit.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

param.name: distanceUnit
param.para: This is the DistanceUnit you would like to use as the measure for the move. For example, if you select miles as your distanceUnit, then the xOffsetDistance and yOffsetDistance will be calculated in miles.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape.TranslateByDegreeCore(System.Double,System.Double,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit)
member.summary: This method moves the shape from one location to another, based on a direction in degrees and distance.
member.overloads: In this overload the distance is in the same GeographicUnit as the shape.

remarks.para: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an angleInDegrees and distance parameter. With this overload, it is important to note that the distance units are the same GeographicUnit as the shape. For example, if your shape is in decimal degrees and you call this method with a distance of 1, you're going to move this shape 1 decimal degree in direction of the angleInDegrees. In many cases it is more useful to specify the DistanceUnit of movement, such as in miles or yards, so for these scenarios there is another overload you may want to use instead.
If you pass a distance of 0, then the operation is ignored.

member.exception: Passing an invalid angleInDegrees which is not between 0 and 360 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on this shape which has invalid upper left and lower right points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
Passing an invalid distance which is not greater than or equal to 0 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.param: The distance is the number of units to move the shape in the angle specified. The distance unit will be the same as the GeographyUnit for the shape. The distance must be greater than or equal to 0.

param.name: angleInDegrees
param.para: A number between 0 and 360 degrees that represents the direction you wish to move the shape, with 0 being up.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

param.name: distanceUnit
param.para: This is the DistanceUnit you would like to use as the measure for the move. For example, if you select miles as your distanceUnit, then the xOffsetDistance and yOffsetDistance will be calculated in miles.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape.GetClosestPointToCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.BaseShape,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit)
member.summary: This method returns the point of the current shape that is closest to the target shape.
member.returns: A PointShape representing the closest point of the current shape to the targetShape.
member.exception: If you pass in a targetShape which does not have any points, we will throw an ArgumentException.
If you pass a null as the targetShape, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
If you pass in a shapeUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.remarks: This method returns the point of the current shape that is closest to the target shape. It is often the case that the point returned is not a point of the object itself. An example would be a line with two points that are far apart from each other. If you set the targetShape to be a point midway between the points but a short distance away from the line, the method would return a point that is on the line but not either of the two points that make up the line.

param.name: targetShape
param.para: The shape you are trying to find the closest point to.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

member.exception: If you pass in a targetShape which does not have any points, we will throw an ArgumentException.
If you pass a null as the targetShape, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
If you pass in a shapeUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a distanceUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.overloads: The distance returned will be in the unit of the shape.
member.returns:
The return type is the distance between this shape and the targetShape in the GeographyUnit of the shape.
Overriding:

member.remarks: In this method, we compute the closest distance between the two shapes. The returned unit will be in the unit of distance specified.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape.GetWellKnownTextCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingOrder)
member.summary: This method returns the well-known text representation of this shape.
member.returns: This method returns a string that represents the shape in well-known text.

remarks.para: This method returns a string that represents the shape in well-known text. Well-known text allows you to describe a geometry as a string of text. Well-known text is useful when you want to save a geometry in a format such as a text file, or when you simply want to cut and paste the text between other applications. An alternative to well-known text is well-known binary, which is a binary representation of a geometry object. We have methods that work with well-known binary as well. Below are some samples of what well-known text might look like for various kinds of geometric shapes.
POINT(5 17)
LINESTRING(4 5,10 50,25 80)

member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method on this shape which has invalid upper left and lower right points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape.ValidateCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationMode)
member.summary: This method returns a ShapeValidationResult based on a series of tests.
member.returns: This method returns a ShapeValidationResult based on a series of tests.
member.remarks: We use this method, with the simple enumeration, internally before doing any kind of other methods on the shape. In this way, we are able to verify the integrity of the shape itself. If you wish to test things such as whether a polygon self-intersects, we invite you to call this method with the advanced ShapeValidationMode. One thing to consider is that for complex polygon shapes this operation could take some time, which is why we only run the basic, faster test. If you are dealing with polygon shapes that are suspect, we suggest you run the advanced test.
member.exception: If you pass in a validationMode that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.param: This parameter determines whether the test is simple or advanced. In some cases, the advanced tests can take some time. The simple test is designed to always be fast.

In this way, we leave our framework open on our end, but also allow you the developer to extend our logic to suit your needs. If you have questions about this, please contact our support team as we would be happy to work with you on extending our framework.

Option 3 is used when you want to return parts of the columns in the feature; in this case you should pass in an (IEnumerable[string] returningColumnNames) instead of using this enumeration directly.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingShape.GetBoundingBoxCore
member.summary: This method calculates the smallest RectangleShape that encompasses the entire geometry.
member.returns: The RectangleShape returned is the smallest RectangleShape that can encompass the entire geometry.

remarks.para: The GetBoundingBox method calculates the smallest RectangleShape that can encompass the entire geometry by examining each point in the geometry.
Depending on the number of PointShapes and complexity of the geometry, this operation can take longer for larger objects.
If the shape is a PointShape, then the bounding box's upper left and lower right points will be equal. This will create a RectangleShape with no area.

member.exception: In the event you attempt to get the bounding box from a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingShape.RegisterCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PointShape,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PointShape,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit)
member.summary: This method returns a BaseShape which has been registered from its original coordinate system to another based on two anchor PointShapes.

returns.para: This method returns a BaseShape which has been registered from its original coordinate system to another based on two anchor PointShapes.

remarks.para: Registering allows you to take a geometric shape generated in a planar system and attach it to the ground in a Geographic Unit.

A common scenario is integrating geometric shapes from external programs (such as CAD software or a modeling system) and placing them onto a map. You may have the schematics of a building in a CAD system and the relationship between all the points of the building are in feet. You want to then take the CAD image and attach it to where it really exists on a map. You would use the register method to do this.

Registering is also useful for scientific modeling, where software models things such as a plume of hazardous materials or the fallout from a volcano. The modeling software typically generates these models in a fictitious planar system. You would then use the register to take the abstract model and attach it to a map with real coordinates.

member.exception: If you pass in a fromUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a toUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
Passing a null as the fromPoint parameter will throw an ArgumentNullException.
Passing a null as the toPoint parameter will throw an ArgumentNullException.
member.param: This parameter is the anchor PointShape in the coordinate of origin.
This parameter is the anchor PointShape in the coordinate of destination.
This parameter is the DistanceUnit of the coordinate of origin.
This parameter is the GeographyUnit of the coordinate of destination.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingShape.TranslateByOffsetCore(System.Double,System.Double,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit)
member.summary: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an X and Y offset distance.
member.overloads: In this overload the X and Y offset are based on the DistanceUnit you specify, regardless of the shape's GeographicUnit.

remarks.para: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an X and Y offset distance. With this overload, it is important to note that the X and Y offset units are based on the distanceUnit parameter. For example, if your shape is in decimal degrees and you call this method with an X offset of 1 and a Y offset of 1, you're going to move this shape 1 unit of the distanceUnit in the horizontal direction and one unit of the distanceUnit in the vertical direction. In this way, you can easily move a shape in decimal degrees five miles to on the X axis and 3 miles on the Y axis.

member.exception: If you pass in a distanceUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a shapeUnit that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method from a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This is the number of horizontal units of movement in the DistanceUnit specified as the distanceUnit.
This is the number of horizontal units of movement in the DistanceUnit specified as the distanceUnit.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

param.name: distanceUnit
param.para: This is the DistanceUnit you would like to use as the measure for the move. For example, if you select miles as your distanceUnit, then the xOffsetDistance and yOffsetDistance will be calculated in miles.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingShape.TranslateByDegreeCore(System.Double,System.Double,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DistanceUnit)
member.summary: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on a distance and a direction in degrees.
member.overloads: In this overload, the distance is in the same GeographicUnit as the shape.

remarks.para: This method moves the base shape from one location to another, based on an angleInDegrees and distance parameter. With this overload, it is important to note that the distance units are the same GeographicUnit as the shape. For example, if your shape is in decimal degrees and you call this method with a distance of 1, you're going to move this shape 1 decimal degree in direction of the angleInDegrees. In many cases it is more useful to specify the DistanceUnit of movement, such as in miles or yards, so for these scenarios there is another overload you may want to use instead.
If you pass a distance of 0, then the operation is ignored.

member.exception: Passing an invalid angleInDegrees which is not between 0 and 360 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method from a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
Passing an invalid distance which is not greater than or equal to 0 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.param: The distance is the number of units to move the shape in the angle specified. The distance unit will be the same as the GeographyUnit for the shape. The distance must be greater than or equal to 0.

param.name: angleInDegrees
param.para: A number between 0 and 360 degrees that represents the direction you wish to move the shape, with 0 being up.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

param.name: distanceUnit
param.para: This is the DistanceUnit you would like to use as the measure for the move. For example, if you select miles as your distanceUnit, then the xOffsetDistance and yOffsetDistance will be calculated in miles.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingShape.RotateCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PointShape,System.Single)
member.summary: This method rotates the shape a number of degrees based on a pivot point.

remarks.para: This method rotates the shape a number of degrees based on a pivot point. By placing the pivot point in the center of the shape, you can achieve in-place rotation. By moving the pivot point outside of the center of the shape, you can translate the shape in a circular motion. Moving the pivot point further outside of the center will make the circular area larger.

member.exception: If you pass a null as the pivotPoint, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
Passing an invalid degreeAngle which is not between 0 and 360 will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which is not valid, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.

param.name: pivotPoint
param.para: The pivotPoint represents the center of rotation.

param.name: degreeAngle
param.para: The number of degrees of rotation required from 0 to 360.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RingShape.GetClosestPointToCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.BaseShape,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.GeographyUnit)
member.summary: This method returns the point of the current shape that is closest to the target shape.
member.returns: A PointShape representing the closest point of the current shape to the targetShape.
member.exception: If you pass in a targetShape which does not have any points, we will throw an ArgumentException.
If you pass a null as the targetShape, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method on a shape which has no points, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.

member.remarks: This method returns the point of the current shape that is closest to the target shape. It is often the case that the point returned is not a point of the object itself. An example would be a line with two points that are far apart from each other. If you set the targetShape to be a point midway between the points but a short distance away from the line, the method would return a point that is on the line but not either of the two points that make up the line.

param.name: shapeUnit
param.para: This is the GeographicUnit of the shape you are performing the operation on.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationMode
member.summary: This enumeration describes the type of validation test to run on shapes.
member.remarks: The simple tests are used internally before any method call is made to a shape. In this way, we have a certain level of confidence that the operation will succeed. The advanced tests are meant to be performed by users if they get a shape from an external source and consider it suspect.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationMode.Simple
member.summary: The simple tests are designed to be very fast.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationMode.Advanced
member.summary: The advanced tests are designed to be comprehensive with no regard to speed.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationResult
member.summary: This structure represents the result of the validation method performed on a shape.
member.remarks: This is used to determine if an validation rule was broken for a shape. This structure also returns the description of the violation.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationResult.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: This constructor allows you to set the IsValid and ValidationErrors properties.
member.remarks: None
member.param: This parameter describes whether the object has passed its validation method.
This parameter describes the list of errors if the object did not pass its validation method. The errors are separated by semicolons.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationResult.IsValid
member.summary: This property describes whether the object has passed its validation method.
member.value: This property returns either true or false, depending on whether the object has passed its validation method.
member.remarks: None

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ShapeValidationResult.ValidationErrors
member.summary: This property describes the list of errors if the object did not pass its validation method.
member.remarks: If there are multiple errors, they will be separated by semicolons. If the object passed its validations, then this string will be empty.
member.value: This property returns the list of errors if the object did not pass its validation method.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ExtentHelper.CenterAt(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.PointShape,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: This is a static function that allows you to pass in a world rectangle, a world point to center on, and a height and width in screen units. The function will center the rectangle based on the point, then adjust the rectangle's ratio based on the height and width in screen coordinates.
member.overloads: This overload allows you to pass in a world point as the center.
member.returns: This method returns an adjusted extent centered on a point.
member.remarks: None
member.param: This parameter is the current extent you want to center.
This parameter is the world point you want to center on.
This parameter is the width of the screen.
This parameter is the height of the screen.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.ExtentHelper.GetDrawingExtent(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.RectangleShape,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: This method returns an adjusted extent based on the ratio of the screen width and height.
member.returns: This method returns an adjusted extent based on the ratio of the screen width and height.
member.remarks: This function is used because the extent to draw must be the rame ratio as the screen width and height. If they are not, then the image drawn will be stretched or compressed. We always adjust the extent upwards to ensure that no matter how we adjust it, the original extent will fit within the new extent. This ensures that everything you wanted to see in the first extent is visible and maybe a bit more.
member.param: This parameter is the world extent you want to adjust for drawing.
This parameter is the width of the screen.
This parameter is the height of the screen.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.SimplificationType
member.summary: Specifies which algorthm will be use to simplify.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.SimplificationType.TopologyPreserving
member.summary: Simplifies a point, ensuring that the result is a valid point having the same dimension and number of components as the input. The simplification uses a maximum distance difference algorithm similar to the one used in the Douglas-Peucker algorithm. In particular, if the input is an areal point ( Polygon or MultiPolygon ) The result has the same number of shells and holes (rings) as the input, in the same order The result rings touch at no more than the number of touching point in the input (although they may touch at fewer points).

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.SimplificationType.DouglasPeucker
member.summary: Simplifies a Geometry using the standard Douglas-Peucker algorithm. Ensures that any polygonal geometries returned are valid. Simple lines are not guaranteed to remain simple after simplification. Note that in general D-P does not preserve topology - e.g. polygons can be split, collapse to lines or disappear holes can be created or disappear, and lines can cross. To simplify point while preserving topology use TopologySafeSimplifier. (However, using D-P is significantly faster).

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.StartingPoint
member.summary: An enumeration describing the place to start on a line when doing certain operations.
member.remarks: Certain kinds of mathematical line operations need to know if the operation will start at the beginning or the end of the line. Whenever this is the case, you'll need to use this enumeration.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType
member.summary: This describes a set of enumerations that list the valid types of geometries.
member.remarks: Each of the geometries listed is either a subset or compatible with the OpenGIS specifications or the simple feature specifications. Each different kind of geometry can also be converted to well-known text and well-known binary. We have added some additional geometry types (such as the ellipse and rectangle) which normally are not included as separate GIS geometries but are very useful and can easily be converted to standard types.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.Invalid
member.summary: An invalid shape type.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.Point
member.summary: A Point is a geometry that represents a single location in coordinate space.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.Line
member.summary: A Line is a curve with linear interpolation between points.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.Polygon
member.summary: A Polygon is a planar surface representing a multisided geometry. It is defined by a single exterior boundary and zero or more interior boundaries, where each interior boundary defines a hole in the Polygon.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.Multipoint
member.summary: A MultiPoint is a geometry collection composed of Point elements. The points are not connected or ordered in any way.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.Multiline
member.summary: A MultiLine is a geometry collection composed of Line elements.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.Multipolygon
member.summary: A MultiPolygon is a object composed of one or more Polygon elements.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WellKnownType.GeometryCollection
member.summary: A GeometryCollection is a object composed of one or more Shape elements.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WkbByteOrder

member.remarks: None

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WkbByteOrder.LittleEndian
member.summary: The least significant byte value is at the lowest address.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.WkbByteOrder.BigEndian
member.summary: The most significant byte value is at the lowest address.

member.summary: This property gets and sets the X pixel offset for drawing each feature.
member.value: This property gets the X pixel offset for drawing each feature.
member.remarks: This property allows you to specify an X offset. When combined with a Y offset, it is useful to allow you to achieve effects such as drop shadows, etc. There also may be times when you need to modify the location of feature data so as to better align it with raster satellite data.

member.summary: This property returns a collection of area styles allowing you to stack multiple area styles on top of each other.
member.value: This property returns a collection of area styles.
member.remarks: Using this collection, you can stack multiple styles on top of each other. When we draw the feature, we will draw them in order that they exist in the collection. You can use these stacks to create drop shadow effects, multiple colored outlines, etc.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointBaseStyle.DrawSampleCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Drawing.GeoCanvas,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DrawingRectangleF)
member.summary: This method draws a sample feature on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This virtual method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we draw a sample style on the canvas you provided. This is typically used to display a legend or other sample area.
When implementing this virtual method, consider the canvas size and draw the sample image appropriately. You should keep in mind that the sample typically shows up on a legend.
member.returns: None
member.exception: If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.Style
member.summary: This abstract class is the root for all styles used for drawing features.
member.remarks:
If you need to create your own style in the future, we suggest that you first consider extending an existing style. If you are doing something new, then you can inherit from this class.
The key method to override is DrawCore. If you want to provide a sample for the legend, you will also want to extend the DrawSampleCore.

member.remarks: This property gets the collection of fields that are required for the style. These are in addition to any other columns you specify in styles that inherit from this one. For example, if you have use a ValueStyle and it requires a column name for the value comparison, then that column does not need to be in this collection. You only use the RequiredColumnNames for columns you need beyond those required by specific inherited styles.

member.summary: This method draws the features on the canvas you provided.
member.returns: None

remarks.para:
This method is the concrete wrapper for the abstract method DrawCore. In this method, we take the features you passed in and draw them on the canvas you provided. Each style (based on its properties) may draw each feature differently.
As this is a concrete public method that wraps a Core method, we reserve the right to add events and other logic to pre- or post-process data returned by the Core version of the method. In this way, we leave our framework open on our end, but also allow you the developer to extend our logic to suit your needs. If you have questions about this, please contact our support team as we would be happy to work with you on extending our framework.

member.exception: If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If you pass a null as the features, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This parameter represents the features you want to draw on the canvas.
This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.
The labels will be drawn in the current layer only.
The labels will be drawn in all layers.

member.summary: This method draws the features on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This abstract method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we take the features you passed in and draw them on the canvas you provided. Each style (based on its properties) may draw each feature differently.
When implementing this abstract method, consider each feature and its column data values. You can use the full power of the GeoCanvas to do the drawing. If you need column data for a feature, be sure to override the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore and add the columns you need to the collection. In many of the styles, we add properties to allow the user to specify which field they need; then, in the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore, we read that property and add it to the collection.
member.returns: None
member.param: This parameter represents the features you want to draw on the canvas.
This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.
The labels will be drawn in the current layer only.
The labels will be drawn in all layers.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.Style.GetRequiredColumnNames
member.summary: This method returns the column data for each feature that is required for the style to properly draw.
member.returns: This method returns a collection of column names that the style needs.

remarks.para:
This method is the concrete wrapper for the abstract method GetRequiredColumnNamesCore. In this method, we return the column names that are required for the style to draw the feature properly. For example, if you have a style that colors areas blue when a certain column value is over 100, then you need to be sure you include that column name. This will ensure that the column data is returned to you in the feature when it is ready to draw.
In many of the styles, we add properties to allow the user to specify which field they need; then, in the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore we read that property and add it to the collection.
As this is a concrete public method that wraps a Core method, we reserve the right to add events and other logic to pre- or post-process data returned by the Core version of the method. In this way, we leave our framework open on our end, but also allow you the developer to extend our logic to suit your needs. If you have questions about this, please contact our support team as we would be happy to work with you on extending our framework.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.Style.GetRequiredColumnNamesCore
member.remarks:
This abstract method is called from the concrete public method GetRequiredFieldNames. In this method, we return the column names that are required for the style to draw the feature properly. For example, if you have a style that colors areas blue when a certain column value is over 100, then you need to be sure you include that column name. This will ensure that the column data is returned to you in the feature when it is ready to draw.
In many of the styles, we add properties to allow the user to specify which field they need; then, in the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore we read that property and add it to the collection.
member.summary: This method returns the column data for each feature that is required for the style to properly draw.
member.returns: This method returns a collection of column names that the style needs.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.AreaStyle.FillSolidBrush
member.summary: This property gets and sets the solid brush you want to use to fill in the area features.
member.value: This property represents the solid brush you want to use to fill in the area features.
member.remarks: This solid brush is used to fill in the area features that will draw. You can also optionally specify an outline pen to give the area an outline. The default solid brush has a fill color of transparent, which means it will not draw anything.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.AreaStyle.CustomAreaStyles
member.summary: This property returns a collection of area styles, allowing you to stack multiple area styles on top of each other.
member.value: This property returns a collection of area styles.
member.remarks: Using this collection, you can stack multiple area styles on top of each other. When we draw the features, we will draw them in order that they exist in the collection. You can use these stacks to create drop shadow effects, multiple colored outlines, etc.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.AreaStyle.OutlinePen
member.summary: This property gets and sets the outline pen you want to use to outline the features.
member.value: This property gets the outline pen you want to use to outline the features.
member.remarks: This outline pen is used to outline the features that will draw. You can also optionally specify a fill brush to give the area a solid fill. The default outline pen color is transparent, which means it will not draw anything.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.AreaStyle.PenBrushDrawingOrder
member.summary: This property gets and sets the pen and brush drawing order.
member.value: This property gets the pen and brush drawing order.
member.remarks: This property controls whether the outline pen or the fill brush is drawn first. The default is for the fill brush to be drawn first. If you have the outline pen draw first then the thickness of the pen will be smaller, creating a subtle but noticeable effect.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.AreaStyle.Advanced
member.summary: This property lets you access the advanced properties of the style.
member.value: This property lets you access the advanced properties of the style.
member.remarks: This property lets you access the advanced properties of the style.

member.summary: This method draws the features on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This overridden method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we take the features you passed in and draw them on the canvas you provided. Each style (based on its properties) may draw each feature differently.
When overriding this method, consider each feature and its column data values. You can use the full power of the GeoCanvas to do the drawing. If you need column data for a feature, be sure to override the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore and add the columns you need to the collection. In many of the styles, we add properties to allow the user to specify which field they need; then, in the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore, we read that property and add it to the collection.
member.returns: None
member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If you pass a null as the features, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If OutlinePen is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If FillSolidBrush is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
member.param: This parameter represents the features you want to draw on the canvas.
This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.
The labels will be drawn in the current layer only.
The labels will be drawn in all layers.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.AreaStyle.DrawSampleCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Drawing.GeoCanvas,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DrawingRectangleF)
member.summary: This method draws a sample feature on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This virtual method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we draw a sample style on the canvas you provided. This is typically used to display a legend or other sample area.
When implementing this virtual method, consider the canvas size and draw the sample image appropriately. You should keep in mind that the sample typically shows up on a legend.
member.returns: None
member.exception: If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.HueFamilyAreaStyle
member.summary: This class is used to draw area features.
member.remarks: You should use this class to draw area features. You can specify a base color and the number of colors you want based on that color to draw the interior, and you can specify an outline pen with which to draw the border. You can optionally choose to use only the outline pen or the fill brush to generate different effects.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LabelDuplicateRule
member.summary: This enumeration defines the different labeling duplicate rules.
member.remarks: Duplicate refers to the condition where a label's text is exactly the same as another label. An example case where this is common is a road where each intersection is its own segment. In such a case, you do not want to label each segment as it would be highly redundant.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LabelDuplicateRule.OneDuplicateLabelPerQuadrant
member.summary: There may be only one label in each of the four quadrants.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LabelDuplicateRule.NoDuplicateLabels
member.summary: There may be no duplicate labels.

member.name: F:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LabelDuplicateRule.UnlimitedDuplicateLabels
member.summary: There may be an unlimited number of duplicate labels.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LabelInformation

member.remarks: This class is used within the labeling logic, specifically in the labeling candidate. The object may represent an entire label or, in the case of a label spline, a single character in the label.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LineStyle
member.summary: This class is the style used to draw lines.
member.remarks: This class is commonly used to draw lines on the GeoCanvas. It is specialized for drawing roads, as this is the main kind of line feature that is most often drawn. You can set an inner, outer and center pen to give you a nice effect. The outer pen draws first, and should typically be black and larger then the inner pen. The inner pen draws next, and should be set as the color of the road you want. It should be thinner than the outer pen. The center pen draws last, and is used to represent a centerline in the road. We suggest that you only use the center pen for highways at low zoom level, as the dashed pen has some performance penalties.

member.summary: This is a constructor for the class.
member.returns: None

member.remarks: Use this when you do not need any additional pens to draw the feature.
member.param: This parameter is the outer pen used to draw the feature.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LineStyle.XOffsetInPixel
member.summary: This property gets and sets the X pixel offset for drawing each feature.
member.value: This property gets the X pixel offset for drawing each feature.
member.remarks: This property allows you to specify an X offset. When combined with a Y offset, it is useful to allow you to achieve effects such as drop shadows, etc. There also may be times when you need to modify the location of feature data so as to better align it with raster satellite data.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LineStyle.YOffsetInPixel
member.summary: This property gets and sets the Y pixel offset for drawing each feature.
member.value: This property gets the Y pixel offset for drawing each feature.
member.remarks: This property allows you to specify an Y offset. When combined with an X offset, it is useful to allow you to achieve effects such as drop shadows, etc. There also may be times when you need to modify the location of feature data so as to better align it with raster satellite data.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LineStyle.CustomLineStyles
member.summary: This property returns a collection of line styles, allowing you to stack multiple line styles on top of each other.
member.value: This property returns a collection of line styles.
member.remarks: Using this collection, you can stack multiple styles on top of each other. When we draw the feature, we will draw them in order that they exist in the collection. You can use these stacks to create drop shadow effects, multiple colored outlines, etc.

member.summary: This method draws the features on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This overridden method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we take the features you passed in and draw them on the canvas you provided. Each style (based on its properties) may draw each feature differently.
When overriding this method, consider each feature and its column data values. You can use the full power of the GeoCanvas to do the drawing. If you need column data for a feature, be sure to override the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore and add the columns you need to the collection. In many of the styles, we add properties to allow the user to specify which field they need; then, in the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore, we read that property and add it to the collection.
member.returns: None
member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If you pass a null as the features, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If OuterPen is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If InnerPen is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If CenterPen is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
member.param: This parameter represents the features you want to draw on the canvas.
This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.
The labels will be drawn in the current layer only.
The labels will be drawn in all layers.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.LineStyle.DrawSampleCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Drawing.GeoCanvas,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DrawingRectangleF)
member.summary: This method draws a sample feature on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This virtual method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we draw a sample style on the canvas you provided. This is typically used to display a legend or other sample area.
When implementing this virtual method, consider the canvas size and draw the sample image appropriately. You should keep in mind that the sample typically shows up on a legend.
member.returns: None
member.exception: If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle
member.summary: This class allows you to define how points are drawn on the canvas.
member.remarks:
This class allows you to define how points are drawn on the canvas. There are three main drawing types: bitmap, character, and symbol. The bitmap allows you to represent each point with a bitmap. The character allows you to choose a font and an index in the font so you can use that character for the point. This is especially helpful with fonts like Wingdings that have many feature-style graphics. The symbol type is a collection of simple geometric symbols that we have assembled to represent abstract items on the map.
When you select a PointType, you need to be sure to set the various properties associated with that type. The property names are prefixed to help you. For example, all of the character-related properties are prefixed with "Character" and the symbol properties follow a similar pattern.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.#ctor
member.summary: This is a constructor for the class.
member.overloads: This is the default constructor. If you use this constructor, you should set the various properties manually.
member.remarks: If you use this constructor, you should set the various properties manually. Specifically, you will want to set the PointType, which allows you to choose between bitmap, character and symbol as an option for displaying your points.
member.returns: None

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.#ctor(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Drawing.GeoImage)
member.summary: This is a constructor for the class.
member.overloads: This constructor is used for bitmap based points.
member.returns: None
member.remarks: If you use this constructor, the PointStyle will be set to Bitmap.
member.param: This parameter is the GeoImage of the image you want to use to display the point.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.PointType
member.summary: This property gets and sets the type of point you want to draw.
member.value: This property gets the type of point you want to draw.
member.remarks: When using the PointStyle you choose between a bitmap, a font or a predefined symbol to represent the point. Each of these options has corresponding properties on the point symbol. If you set the type to character, then you need to set the properties that start with "Character," such as "CharacterFont." The same is true for the symbol.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.Image
member.summary: This property gets and sets the image used if the PointType property is Bitmap.
member.value: This property gets the image used if the PointType property is Bitmap.
member.remarks: This property is where you can set the image for the points if the PointType is Bitmap. It uses a GeoImage, so you can either reference a file or supply a stream.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.ImageScale
member.summary: This property gets and sets the scale of the image you want to draw.
member.value: This property gets the scale of the image you want to draw.
member.remarks: This property allows you to scale the image up and down depending on how large or small you want it. It can be changed dynamically, so you could change it at every scale level to resize the bitmap based on the current scale. A scale of 1 would be the original size, while a scale of 2 would double the size. A scale of .5 would reduce the size of the image by half, and so on.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.CharacterFont
member.summary: This property gets and sets the font that is used for the character if the PointType is Character.
member.value: This property gets the font that is used for the character if the PointType is Character.
member.remarks: This property allows you to set the font from which to select a character index if you choose the Character PointType.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.CharacterIndex
member.summary: This property gets and sets the index position of the character you want to use from the font you selected in the CharacterFont property.
member.value: This property gets the index position of the character you want to use from the font you selected in the CharacterFont property.
member.remarks: You need to specify the index position of the character you want to use from the font you selected. For example, if you choose 1, then we will use the first character in the font you set in the CharacterFont property.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.CharacterSolidBrush
member.summary: This property gets and sets the SolidBrush used to color the font character for the point.
member.value: This property gets the SolidBrush used to color the font character for the point.
member.remarks: This brush is used to draw the character. It is only used if the PointType is Character. If you need a brush other than the SolidBrush, you should look in the advanced property of the class.

member.name: P:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.SymbolType
member.summary: This property gets and sets the type of symbol you want to use if the PointType is Symbol.
member.value: This property gets the type of symbol you want to use if the PointType is Symbol.
member.remarks: You can choose between a number of predefined symbols. The symbols are simple geometric objects that are typically used for abstract representations on a map. If there is a specific symbol you need that is not part of our symbol collection, you can submit it to us and we will consider adding it.

member.summary: This method draws the features on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This overridden method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we take the features you passed in and draw them on the canvas you provided. Each style (based on its properties) may draw each feature differently.
When overriding this method, consider each feature and its column data values. You can use the full power of the GeoCanvas to do the drawing. If you need column data for a feature, be sure to override the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore and add the columns you need to the collection. In many of the styles, we add properties to allow the user to specify which field they need; then, in the GetRequiredColumnNamesCore, we read that property and add it to the collection.
member.returns: None
member.exception: In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If you pass a null as the features, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If symbolPen is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If symbolSolidBrush is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If characterSolidBrush is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If characterFont is null, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
If you pass in a pointSymbolType that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a pointType that is not defined in the enumeration, it will throw a ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
If you pass in a imageScale that is less or equal to 0, it will throw an ArgumentOutOfRangeException.
member.param: This parameter represents the features you want to draw on the canvas.
This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.
The labels will be drawn in the current layer only.
The labels will be drawn in all layers.

member.name: M:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyle.DrawSampleCore(ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Drawing.GeoCanvas,ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Shapes.DrawingRectangleF)
member.summary: This method draws a sample feature on the canvas you provided.
member.remarks:
This virtual method is called from the concrete public method Draw. In this method, we draw a sample style on the canvas you provided. This is typically used to display a legend or other sample area.
When implementing this virtual method, consider the canvas size and draw the sample image appropriately. You should keep in mind that the sample typically shows up on a legend.
member.returns: None
member.exception: If you pass a null as the canvas, we will throw an ArgumentNullException.
In the event you attempt to call this method when the GeoCanvas's IsDrawing mode is false, it will throw an InvalidOperationException.
member.param: This parameter represents the canvas you want to draw the features on.

member.name: T:ThinkGeo.MapSuite.Styles.PointStyles
member.summary: This class provides commonly-used GeoPointStyles and some methods to create various kinds of GeoPointstyles. A GeoStyle is a kind of sheet used to render the map.
member.remarks: The GeoStyle is a very important concept. MapSuite provides three kinds of styles: GeoAreaStyle, GeoLineStyle, and GeoPointStyle. GeoAreaStyle is used to render area-type data on the map, GeoLineStyle is used to render line-type data on the map, GeoPointStyle is used to render point-type data on the map.

member.summary: Use the centroid as polygon's labeling location
